step.title: Design and requirements for automotive, bus and truck

paragraph.htmltext:
Selecting RESS

The used RESS shall be installed accordance with the instructions provided by the RESS manufacturer and conform to the delivered information about the characteristics of the RESS. The used RESS shall comply to the requirements for the regulation of approval of a RESS
Physical requirements

Mechanical retention system to attach components and the battery system to the vehicle should provide for retention in the three mutually perpendicular axes. Sufficient structural strength is required to withstand severe contact loads from FMVSS Crash conditions and rollover without ejecting modules or while providing clearance to the vehicle body. Retention should be sufficient to prevent damage to the batteries by repetitive motion contact. In addition it is necessary to provide retention to protect the battery and the vehicle from damage or affect overall pack reliability.

The retention of the system provides also protection for the passengers and third parties during a vehicle crash. It needs to:

  • Prevent that the pack penetrates into the passenger compartment when it is located outside this compartment
  • Limit the movement of the pack to ensure the safety of the occupants when it is located inside the passenger compartment.
  • Prevent that the pack and its components is ejected from the vehicle after a crash.

Retention should also be sufficient to prevent vibrations/low frequency noises that may reduce structural reliability or be objectionable to passengers. Some designs may also include isolation mounts to reduce NVH.

Clearances on the vehicle that are adequate to enable easy installation or removal of a battery pack should be verified during vehicle design to simplify service operations. SAE J1555 and SAE J2184 may need to be evaluated to prevent interferenceâ€™s with the battery systems. The information on how to install and remove the battery pack shall be provided by the vehicle manufacturer via detailed service information and training to service personnel

The design shall take into account that there is enough clearance between the ground and the battery system to protect the structural integrity and durability. Body clearance spacing may be required to provide adequate protection of the battery system components movement to preclude contact of the battery pack or components to the vehicle. These limits are specified as part of the manufacturers design for manufacture/assembly/service guidelines to assist in developing a robust design. Battery packs should be located to reduce probability of damage. Locating battery packs in susceptible locations should consider use of additional crash structure to protect the battery.
Electrical requirements

An electrical mode of operation can be associated with an operation mode of the vehicle. These are:

  • Key on Discharge
    For normal operation components should be matched to the vehicle system demand. Excess current should be used for the vehicle electrical propulsion and the auxiliary equipment. The system should limit occurrence and amount of over-discharge of individual battery cells. To avoid damaged in abnormal situations, Devices like fusing or rapid response contactors should be considered to provide isolation for ground faults, and over current protection.
  • Charge (including end of charge while plugged in)
    When external charge is used, individual components should match to the vehicle system charge acceptance capability. To develop an appropriate charge algorithm to provide to the pack, consultancy with the battery manufacturer is necessary.
  • Regeneration
    In regeneration energy is recover in lieu of or parallel with the braking action using the motor. During this action the battery voltage should not be allowed to exceed the voltage limits. Recommended profiles of the pack supplier shall be followed.
  • Key off Charge (including end of charge while plugged in)
  • Parked - off charging plug
  • Operational
  • Storage
    When placed in storage the operator shall be able to disconnect the battery circuit. During long term storage, self discharge will occur for most types. Charge capability to boost the battery system to prevent permanent capacity loss may be needed as a routine maintenance program. It may be desirable to attach the pack to a monitoring tool to enable diagnostics and external controls.

Both battery and vehicle manufacturer should agree upon the type of fastener that is used to connect the high power leads to the terminal. Vibration, creep, thermal environment, number of times fastener removed and reinstalled, should be considered in system design. The connector used to mate with the terminal land area and cable or bussbar shall be adequate to carry maximum expected current without heat generation that would cause damage to battery modules or interconnects. Terminal torque affects current carrying capability, and is affected by vibration and creep.
During the design the standards for meeting applicable and useful EMC and transient emissions and susceptibility performance.

A monitor and control system can improve the battery system health and life. The vehicle manufacturer should enable the battery controls to communicate with the remainder of the appropriate vehicle controls to promote limit management and diagnostics.

Electrical isolation of the battery pack both external and internal to the pack should be provided regardless of operating mode including exceptional circumstances. The measurement of the isolation resistance of the battery pack shall include auxiliary components located inside the pack housing, e.g. monitoring or temperature-conditioning devices and liquid fluids (if any). The terminals of the pack have generally different isolation resistances against the electric chassis. For safety reasons, the lower one is regarded as the relevant pack isolation resistance. Standards give procedure to measure this isolation resistance.

Persons need to be protected against electric shock. This protection shall be composed of a basic protection measures against direct contact with live parts and measures for protection under single-failure conditions. The protection measures against direct contact shall be provided by either one or both of the following:

  • Basic insulation of the live parts:
    the live parts of the electric system are totally encapsulated by insulation that can be removed only by destruction. The insulating material shall be suitable to the maximum working voltage and temperature ratings of the vehicle and its systems

  • Barriers/enclosures, preventing access to the live parts:
    the live parts are placed inside enclosures or behind barriers, preventing access to the live parts from any usual direction of access. The barriers/enclosures shall provide sufficient mechanical resistance under normal operating conditions, as specified by the manufacturer. If barriers/enclosures are accessible directly, they shall be opened or removed only by use of tools or maintenance keys or they shall have means to deactivate live parts with class B voltage, e.g. an interlock.

For protection under single failure conditions the following measures can be used:

  • potential equalization
  • isolation resistance
  • capacitive couplings
  • de-energization

To test the protection measures against electric shock, standards give specific procedure (see ‘Tests’).
Standards give requirements for the vehicle power inlet. Requirement on the de-energize, grounding and isolation r esistance are given
Environmental requirements

The first environmental requirement is the temperature range of the electric vehicle. Thermal design approaches should consider EV systems temperature performance ranges. A good measure for temperature range in an EV should be â€“40 Â°C to 60 Â°C with a relative humidity range of 10% to 80% at 38 Â°C .

The second are the requirement for to handle hazardous physical emissions. Under normal operation (shipping and handling, road hazards, storage and normal driving) no electrolyte leakage from or within the battery pack system should occur. A concern is electrolyte leakage causing ionic conductance in a high voltage system, which, without the proper safety circuits, may energize the vehicle chassis. Performance testing and actual leakage allowed at crash situations should be tested and evaluated according to the specific standards.

The third are the requirement for to handle gaseous emissions. The gas emissions may fall into either of two categories of toxic and flammable gasses. It is up to the vehicle manufacturer to follow the battery manufacturerâ€™s recommended charging procedures and to certify hydrogen gas emissions from their vehicle to ascertain whether ventilation is required . It is also up to the discretion of the vehicle manufacturer whether to use hydrogen vent tubes in their design. Places for containing open type traction batteries which may produce hydrogen gas shall be provided with a ventilation fan or duct to prevent accumulation. Tests are described to determine the hydrogen emissions for this situation.

Technical safety guidelines

Safety guidelines information should be considered when designing electric vehicles for use on public roadways. The following guidelines can be found in the standards (SAE J2344, ...)

• Crashworthiness
  • A single-point failure of hardware/software or a single failure of a trained personnel should not result in unreasonable safety risk to any person.
  • Fault monitoring needs to alerte the vehicle operator when there is a system fault or condition that could lead to further damage. Some instances of faults which might need to be indicated are low of high voltage system isolation, low SOC, low oil pressure, temperature out of range, hazardous voltage fault, failure of contactor, ...
  • Safety measures need to be taken to avoid leakage of hazardous liquids and escaping of hazardous gas
  • Total or partial immersion of the vehicle in water should not results in electric potential or current flow, gas or liquid emissions or explosion that is hazardous to any person inside or outside the vehicle.

• All electrical assemblies should be functionally tolerant of the electromagnetic environment to which the vehicle will be exposed. Electrical transients resulting from normal operations should not cause false shutdown of the vehicle.

• Safety labels should be adequate to warn of reasonably foreseeable hazards associated with operation and service of the propulsion system hardware. Hazardous voltage equipment or compartments containing hazardous voltage equipment should be identified using the high voltage symbol.
  • Vehicles that require transfer from off-board sources should include power level available communication.

• Unintended motion must be prevented when the vehicle is stopped. This can be done by the use of a shift mechanism with “P” position in which a mechanical interlock is used to prevent this motion. Vehicle whose shift mechanism does not include a designated “Park” position should provide an obvious means of preventing unintended “rollaway”. Specific procedures for sling, wheel-lift or car-carrier towing shall be included in the owner’s manual/guide.
• The vehicles with a high voltage RESS may be equipped with a gauge that indicates the propulsion system SOC.
Electrical safety

The persons working on the vehicle or in the vehicle shall be protected against the electrical hazards. This means that under normal operating conditions adequate isolation is achieved through physical separation means such as the use of insulated wire, enclosures, or other barriers to direct contact. The degradation of isolation or loss of separation should be detected so that action can be taken to mitigate the degradation. For maintenance or repair, processes and/or hardware should be provided to allow for controlled access to the high-voltage system.

A number of alternative means may be used to achieve these electrical safety goals. The intention of all these means is either to prevent inadvertent contact with hazardous voltages or to prevent damage or injury from the uncontrolled release of electrical energy. The following means can be used:

• Isolation: Electrical isolation of the battery pack from the vehicle chassis, and both external and internal to the pack should be provided regardless of operating mode including exceptional circumstances. The RESS isolation resistance within the vehicle can be tested with procedures from standards like ISO 6469-1 . The amount of required isolation resistance depends on the use of separated DC- and AC-busses, the use of fuel cell.

• High voltage withstand capability: each high voltage system should demonstrate adequate dielectric strength such that there is no indication of a dielectric breakdown or flashover after the application of a voltage

• Automatic hazardous voltage disconnects: These types of disconnect provides a means of electrically separating hazardous voltage of the high voltage source from external circuitry or components without user intervention. The disconnection is based on some triggering event. It should proved a reset capability for restoring the the traction voltage after the initiating condition has been cleared. Typical inputs for these devices are: crash sensor, detection of the loss of high voltage isolation, hazardous voltage interlock loop and overcurrent. Some guidelines need to be taken into account during the design of the automatic disconnect function:
    • The device should be placed as close to the high voltage source output terminals as possible
    • Reset of the device should require a deliberate action of the operator
    • Where practical the device should detect failures of its function and proved indication of such condition
    • An automatic disconnect should not require power to actuate
    • An automatic disconnect should actuate when any associated supply voltage(s) falls to a level below which the disconnect may not function properly.
    • An output signal may be needed from the automatic disconnect to permit de-energizing other power sources on the load side of the automatic disconnect.

• Manual disconnects: A Manual Disconnect can provide manually operated hazardous voltage electrical isolation for vehicle assembly, service, and maintenance operations. The following guidelines are provided for manual disconnects:
    • Any voltage between positive and negative RESS output terminals should be removed when opening the manual disconnect
    • Opening or removal of the manual disconnect should not require tools and should require a force that a person can easily proved.
    • Where practical the device should detect failures of its function and proved indication of such condition

• Interlocks
    • When the high voltage circuitry is disconnected from the source, it may be necessary to discharge the capacitance of the hazardous voltage bus to a non-hazardous level
    • An interlock, or other means, may be provided on any cover whose removal provides direct access to exposed conductors with hazardous voltage.
    • A Hazardous Voltage Interlock Loop (HVIL) is a type of interlock system which typically uses a small (non-hazardous) signal through a loop connecting a set of conductors and connectors where hazardous voltage is present to check for electrical continuity. In the event of a loss of electrical continuity through the loop, for example due to opening a connector, the automatic disconnect device is opened to remove hazardous voltage from potentially exposed points.
    • There should be no accessible contacts carrying hazardous voltage during or in connection with charging operations
    • An interlock that will prevent application of drive power while the vehicle is still mechanically connected to the charging power source shall be implemented

• Special tools may be appropriate in some cases as a substitute for interlocks and automatic disconnects for restricting access to non-user-serviceable functions. They should in general not be used as a substitute for fail-safe design features. The use of specific tools needs to be coupled with safety handling procedures and/or labelling practices.

• The intent of this guideline is that disconnecting a wiring harness used to provide indirect case grounding should also disconnect the source of hazardous voltages. RESS and major power electronics components should have their external conductive cases connected directly to the vehicle conductive structure (chassis) by a ground strap, wire, welded connection or other suitable low-resistance mechanical connection. Case ground connectors routed from other components (as noted as follows) should be connected to this grounding means. Other components which receive hazardous voltages from sources outside their conductive enclosures may have their cases grounded either directly as previously stated or indirectly through the wiring harness which carries the voltage(s) from the external source.
• Guidelines for high voltage wiring assemblies for electric vehicles are available in standards (e.g. SAE J1654, SAE J1673)
• Standards (e.g. SAE J1742) give test methods and general performance requirements for connectors for high voltage components for hybrid vehicles.

• Fuses are protective devices designed to interrupt the electrical circuit when subjected to excessive current. They are nonreversible and must be replaced after the circuit malfunction is corrected. As they do not respond sensitively enough to protect persons from injury due to contact with hazardous high voltage, they should not be used as personnel protection devices.

Operational saftey

This section describe which kind of action the driver must take to safely switch the vehicle in the desirable operation mode (power on, driving forwards and backward, parking, power off, external charging) and which information should be communicated to the driver.

For the power on â€“ power off procedure the following applies:

  • At least two deliberate and distinctive actions shall be performed in order to go from the power-off mode to the driving-enabled mode.
  • Only one action is required to go from the driving-enabled mode to the power-off mode.
  • A main switch function shall be an integral part of the power-on/power-off procedure.
  • It shall be indicated to the driver, continuously or temporarily, that the propulsion system of the electrically propelled vehicles is ready for driving. However, this provision does not apply under conditions where an internal combustion engine provides directly or indirectly the vehicleÂ´s propulsion power.
  • After an automatic or manual turn-off of the propulsion system, it shall only be possible to reactivate it by the power-on procedure, as described.

When the user is driving the vehicle, significant reduction of the vehicle propulsion power should be indicated to the user. A low energy content of the battery pack shall be indicated to the driver if this low SOC has a relevant impact on the vehicle driving performance. During this state of low SOC it shall be possible to move the vehicle out of the traffic area using its own propulsion system and a minimum energy reserve shall be available for the lighting system in the case that there is no independent energy storage for the auxiliary systems.

Driving backwards can be achieved by reversing the rotational direction of the electric motor. When this is the case unintentional switching into reverse when the vehicle is in motion shall be prevented. This requires that for switching between forward and backward direction two separate actions of the driver are needed or a safety device which allow the transition only when the vehicle is stationary or moving slowly. The state of drive direction control shall be indicated to the driver.
When the driver leaves the vehicle, an indication needs to be given wether the electric propulsion system is still in the driving-enable mode.

Protection against failures

The design of systems and components specific to electrically propelled vehicles shall consider fail-safe design.

Measures shall be implemented to manage credible single-point failures.

Unintentional acceleration, deceleration and reversal of direction of a vehicle caused by single-point hardware or software failures (first failures) in systems and components specific to electrically propelled vehicles shall be minimized.
